elements.content: To explore the influence of ligand backbones on the structures of coordination architectures, three structurally related rodlike ligands bearing different backbones, 1,4-bis(benzoimidazol-1-yl)-phenyl (L 1 ), 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)-benzene (L 2 ), and 4,4′-bis(imidazol-1-yl)-biphenyl (L 3 ), have been employed to react with Co(ClO4)2·6H2O, and three three-dimensional interpenetrating coordination polymers, {[Co(L 1 ) 2 ](ClO 4 ) 2 }∞ (1), {[Co(L 2 ) 3 ](ClO 4 ) 2 (CHCl 3 ) 2 }∞ (2), and {[Co(L 3 ) 3 ](ClO 4 ) 2 }∞ (3), have been obtained under similar conditions. Compound 1 forms a 3-fold interpenetrating network with diamondoid topology based on a tetrahedrally coordinated CoII node, whereas complex 2 takes a double interpenetrating network with α-polonium-type topology and compound 3 exhibits a 3-fold interpenetrating network with β-Sn topology. Compared with the tetrahedrally coordinated CoII node in compound 1, the CoII nodes in compounds 2 and 3 are both octahedrally coordinated. To the best of our knowledge, the 3-fold interpenetrating network of compound 3 is the first example of β-Sn 485463 topology in coordination polymers. Our results reveal that ligand backbones (including terminal groups and spacer conformations) may be the major influence on the structure topology of coordination architectures, and significantly, the coordination mode and spacer length play important role in controlling the degree of interpenetration of coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text: To explore the influence of ligand backbones on the structures of coordination architectures, three structurally related rodlike ligands bearing different backbones, 1,4-bis(benzoimidazol-1-yl)-phenyl (L  1 ), 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)-benzene (L  2 ), and 4,4'-bis(imidazol-1-yl)-biphenyl (L  3 ), have been employed to react with Co(ClO4)2⋅6H2O, and three three-dimensional interpenetrating coordination polymers, {[Co(L  1  )  2  ](ClO  4  )  2  }∞  (1), {[Co(L  2  )  3  ](ClO  4  )  2  (CHCl  3  )  2  }∞  (2), and {[Co(L  3  )  3  ](ClO  4  )  2  }∞  (3), have been obtained under similar conditions. Compound 1 forms a 3-fold interpenetrating network with diamondoid topology based on a tetrahedrally coordinated CoII node, whereas complex 2 takes a double interpenetrating network with α-polonium-type topology and compound 3 exhibits a 3-fold interpenetrating network with β-Sn topology. Compared with the tetrahedrally coordinated CoII node in compound 1, the CoII nodes in compounds 2 and 3 are both octahedrally coordinated. To the best of our knowledge, the 3-fold interpenetrating network of compound 3 is the first example of β-Sn 485463 topology in coordination polymers. Our results reveal that ligand backbones (including terminal groups and spacer conformations) may be the major influence on the structure topology of coordination architectures, and significantly, the coordination mode and spacer length play important role in controlling the degree of interpenetration of coordination polymers.

elements.content: To investigate the relationships between the structures of coordination polymers with organic bridging ligands, three structure-related rodlike bisimidazole ligands have been used to react with Co(ClO4)2·6H2O and three coordination polymers showing different interpenetration have been obtained. The results show that the interpenetration of the coordination architectures could be modulated by varying the ligand backbones.
elements.clean_text: To investigate the relationships between the structures of coordination polymers with organic bridging ligands, three structure-related rodlike bisimidazole ligands have been used to react with Co(ClO4)2⋅6H2O and three coordination polymers showing different interpenetration have been obtained. The results show that the interpenetration of the coordination architectures could be modulated by varying the ligand backbones.

elements.content: In the past decades, the design of functional coordination polymers is of great interest for their intriguing structures and topologies, as well as for their potential application as functional materials. As a common phenomena in crystal engineering, network interpenetration plays an important role in porous coordination polymers. Although interpenetration is considered to have negative influence on the size and accessibility of pores, it may help to support large porous frameworks. Typical example is MOF-9 with 2-fold interpenetrating network, which exhibits a stable and high porous architecture, and has the most available free volume of 71%. Although the investigation on interpenetrating networks developed rapidly and continues to provide new fascinating topologies, the goal of predicting and control of interpenetration remains a long-term challenge. It is most likely related to the length of ligand spacers, but factors that affect the framework topology and degree of interpenetration are complicated in the formation of coordination polymers. In addition, great progress in coordination polymers with mixed ligands has led to many discussions on controlling the diversity of interpenetrating networks, and it was vigorously pursued to tune the degree of interpenetration by altering only the auxiliary ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In the past decades, the design of functional coordination polymers is of great interest for their intriguing structures and topologies, as well as for their potential application as functional materials. As a common phenomena in crystal engineering, network interpenetration plays an important role in porous coordination polymers. Although interpenetration is considered to have negative influence on the size and accessibility of pores, it may help to support large porous frameworks. Typical example is MOF-9 with 2-fold interpenetrating network, which exhibits a stable and high porous architecture, and has the most available free volume of 71%. Although the investigation on interpenetrating networks developed rapidly and continues to provide new fascinating topologies, the goal of predicting and control of interpenetration remains a long-term challenge. It is most likely related to the length of ligand spacers, but factors that affect the framework topology and degree of interpenetration are complicated in the formation of coordination polymers. In addition, great progress in coordination polymers with mixed ligands has led to many discussions on controlling the diversity of interpenetrating networks, and it was vigorously pursued to tune the degree of interpenetration by altering only the auxiliary ligand.

elements.content: Imidazole has been well-used in crystal engineering, and some zeolite-like porous frameworks with divalent and tetrahedral metal ions with this ligand have been reported. Meanwhile, a large number of imidazole-containing flexible ligands have been extensively studied, and many fascinating coordination polymers based on such poly(imidazole) ligands have been synthesized. However, to the best of our knowledge, the research on imidazole ligands bearing rigid spacers is still less developed.
elements.clean_text: Imidazole has been well-used in crystal engineering, and some zeolite-like porous frameworks with divalent and tetrahedral metal ions with this ligand have been reported. Meanwhile, a large number of imidazole-containing flexible ligands have been extensively studied, and many fascinating coordination polymers based on such poly(imidazole) ligands have been synthesized. However, to the best of our knowledge, the research on imidazole ligands bearing rigid spacers is still less developed.

elements.content: To explore the influence of ligand backbones (including terminal groups and spacer conformations) on the structures of coordination architectures, in this work, three structurally related rod-like ligands with different backbones, 1,4-bis(benzoimidazol-1-yl)phenyl (L 1 ), 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene (L 2 ), and 4,4′-bis(imidazol-1-yl)biphenyl (L 3 ) (Chart ), have been employed to react with Co(ClO4)2·6H2O, and three new coordination polymers, {[Co(L 1 ) 2 ](ClO 4 ) 2 }∞ (1), {[Co(L 2 ) 3 ](ClO 4 ) 2 (CHCl 3 ) 2 }∞ (2), and {[Co(L 3 ) 3 ](ClO 4 ) 2 }∞ (3), have been obtained. These results reveal that ligand backbones have great influence on the topology of coordination architectures and may be used as a tool to tune the degree of interpenetrations.
elements.clean_text: To explore the influence of ligand backbones (including terminal groups and spacer conformations) on the structures of coordination architectures, in this work, three structurally related rod-like ligands with different backbones, 1,4-bis(benzoimidazol-1-yl)phenyl (L  1 ), 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene (L  2 ), and 4,4'-bis(imidazol-1-yl)biphenyl (L  3 ) (Chart ), have been employed to react with Co(ClO4)2⋅6H2O, and three new coordination polymers, {[Co(L  1  )  2  ](ClO  4  )  2  }∞  (1), {[Co(L  2  )  3  ](ClO  4  )  2  (CHCl  3  )  2  }∞  (2), and {[Co(L  3  )  3  ](ClO  4  )  2  }∞  (3), have been obtained. These results reveal that ligand backbones have great influence on the topology of coordination architectures and may be used as a tool to tune the degree of interpenetrations.

<label>1</label>
<graphic id="gr4" orientation="portrait" position="anchor" xlink:href="cg-2008-01250g_0001.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

All the solvents and reagents for synthesis were commercially available and used as received. Ligands 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene (L 2 ) and 4,4′-bis(imidazol-1-yl)biphenyl (L 3 ) were synthesized according to literature procedures. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer, and IR spectra were measured on a TENSOR 27 (Bruker) FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AC-P500 spectrometer (300 MHz) in CDCl3 medium at 25 °C with tetramethylsilane as the internal reference.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Procedures

All the solvents and reagents for synthesis were commercially available and used as received. Ligands 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene (L  2 ) and 4,4'-bis(imidazol-1-yl)biphenyl (L  3 ) were synthesized according to literature procedures. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer, and IR spectra were measured on a TENSOR 27 (Bruker) FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AC-P500 spectrometer (300 MHz) in CDCl3 medium at 25 °C with tetramethylsilane as the internal reference.

elements.content: A mixture of 1,4-dibromophenyl (12.0 mmol), benzoimidazole (60.0 mmol), CuI (2.5 mmol), 1,10-phenanthroline (6.0 mmol), and K2CO3 (96.0 mmol) was suspended in 50 mL of DMF. The mixture was refluxed for ca. 5 days and then cooled to room temperature. The resulting residue was extracted with CH2Cl2 (50 mL × 3), and the organic extracts were combined, dried over MgSO4, and purified by column chromatography (v/v 2:1 CHCl3/CH3CO2Et) to afford L 1 as white powder (yield ∼35%, based on 1,4-dibromophenyl). 300-MHz 1H NMR (δ, CDCl3): 8.20 (2H, s), 7.93 (2H, m), 7.77 (4H, s), 7.62 (2H, m), 7.40 (4H, m). Anal. Calcd for C20H14N4: C, 77.40; H, 4.55; N, 18.05%. Found: C, 77.61; H, 4.45; N, 18.19. IR (KBr, cm −1): 3476s, 3416s, 3114m, 3064m, 3021m, 1612m, 1520s, 1486s, 1455s, 1277m, 1227s, 1146m, 978m, 892m, 845s, 746s, 633m, 589m, 503w, 438m. MS: m/z = 311.9 for (HL 1 )+.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 1,4-Bis(benzoimidazol-1-yl)phenyl (L1) 

A mixture of 1,4-dibromophenyl (12.0 mmol), benzoimidazole (60.0 mmol), CuI (2.5 mmol), 1,10-phenanthroline (6.0 mmol), and K2CO3 (96.0 mmol) was suspended in 50 mL of DMF. The mixture was refluxed for ca. 5 days and then cooled to room temperature. The resulting residue was extracted with CH2Cl2 (50 mL × 3), and the organic extracts were combined, dried over MgSO4, and purified by column chromatography (v/v 2:1 CHCl3/CH3CO2Et) to afford L  1  as white powder (yield ~35%, based on 1,4-dibromophenyl). 300-MHz 1H NMR (δ, CDCl3): 8.20 (2H, s), 7.93 (2H, m), 7.77 (4H, s), 7.62 (2H, m), 7.40 (4H, m). Anal. Calcd for C20H14N4: C, 77.40; H, 4.55; N, 18.05%. Found: C, 77.61; H, 4.45; N, 18.19. IR (KBr, cm -1): 3476s, 3416s, 3114m, 3064m, 3021m, 1612m, 1520s, 1486s, 1455s, 1277m, 1227s, 1146m, 978m, 892m, 845s, 746s, 633m, 589m, 503w, 438m. MS: m/z = 311.9 for (HL  1 )+.

elements.content: A mixture of C2H5OH and CHCl3 (1:1, 8 mL), as a buffer layer, was carefully layered over a solution of L 1 (0.06 mmol) in CHCl3 (6 mL). A solution of Co(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.02 mmol) in C2H5OH (6 mL) was then layered over the buffer layer, and the resultant reaction was left to stand at room temperature. After ca. 3 weeks, purple block single crystals appeared at the boundary. Yield: ∼30% (based on L 1 ). Anal. Calcd for C40H28CoCl2O8N8: C, 54.68; H, 3.21; N, 12.75%. Found: C, 54.88; H, 3.13; N, 12.63. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3472s, 3416s, 1641m, 1618m, 1524m, 1462s, 1295w, 1245m, 1123s, 1094s, 849m, 746w, 619s, 488w.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {[Co(L1)2](ClO4)2} ∞   (1)

A mixture of C2H5OH and CHCl3 (1:1, 8 mL), as a buffer layer, was carefully layered over a solution of L  1  (0.06 mmol) in CHCl3 (6 mL). A solution of Co(ClO4)2⋅6H2O (0.02 mmol) in C2H5OH (6 mL) was then layered over the buffer layer, and the resultant reaction was left to stand at room temperature. After ca. 3 weeks, purple block single crystals appeared at the boundary. Yield: ~30% (based on L  1 ). Anal. Calcd for C40H28CoCl2O8N8: C, 54.68; H, 3.21; N, 12.75%. Found: C, 54.88; H, 3.13; N, 12.63. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3472s, 3416s, 1641m, 1618m, 1524m, 1462s, 1295w, 1245m, 1123s, 1094s, 849m, 746w, 619s, 488w.

 {[Co(L2)3](ClO4)2(CHCl3)2}∞  (2)

Yield: ~30% (based on L  2 ). IR (KBr, cm-1): 3596m, 3528m, 3131m, 3038w, 2012w, 1638w, 1530s, 1489m, 1442w, 1322m, 1306s, 1268w, 1245m, 1090s, 1074s, 962m, 933m, 834m, 763m, 659m, 622m, 548m, 491w, 449w.

elements.content:
Yield: ∼30% (based on L 3 ). IR (KBr, cm−1): 3491w, 3135m, 3045w, 2019w, 1609m, 1515s, 1410w, 1337w, 1310s, 1246m, 1093s, 1066s, 1006w, 963m, 934w, 822m, 738m, 688w, 661m, 621m, 565w, 533w, 452w.

Caution! Although we have met no problems in handling perchlorate salt during this work, these should be treated cautiously because of their potentially explosive nature.

X-ray Crystallographic Measurements for <bold>1</bold>−<bold>3</bold>

X-ray single-crystal diffraction data of 1-3 were collected on a Rigaku MM-007/Saturn 70 with graphite monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. All the structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods with SHELXL. Metal atoms in each complex were located from the E-maps and other non-hydrogen atoms were located in successive difference Fourier syntheses and refined with anisotropic thermal parameters on F 2. All the ligand L 1 molecules in 1 were disordered and split into two parts for each disordered atom. Moreover, the ClO4 − anions in 1 and 2 were also disordered. In compound 1, one ClO4 − anion was treated as a bitetrahedron mode, whereas the disordered ClO4 − anion of 2 was treated as a spindle-shaped mode. Although we tried several times to obtain better crystals, the quality of the single crystals for complex 3 were not good enough. Solvent molecules in structure 3 were highly disordered, which caused a high R value. To resolve this issue, we removed the contribution of solvent electron density by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON. The hydrogen atoms of the ligands were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically with fixed thermal factors. Further details for structural analysis are summarized in Table , and selected bond lengths and angles for compounds 1−3 are listed in Table .

  Caution!  Although we have met no problems in handling perchlorate salt during this work, these should be treated cautiously because of their potentially explosive nature. 

X-ray Crystallographic Measurements for 1-3 

X-ray single-crystal diffraction data of 1-3 were collected on a Rigaku MM-007/Saturn 70 with graphite monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. All the structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods with SHELXL. Metal atoms in each complex were located from the E-maps and other non-hydrogen atoms were located in successive difference Fourier syntheses and refined with anisotropic thermal parameters on F 2. All the ligand L  1  molecules in 1 were disordered and split into two parts for each disordered atom. Moreover, the ClO4 - anions in 1 and 2 were also disordered. In compound 1, one ClO4 - anion was treated as a bitetrahedron mode, whereas the disordered ClO4 - anion of 2 was treated as a spindle-shaped mode. Although we tried several times to obtain better crystals, the quality of the single crystals for complex 3 were not good enough. Solvent molecules in structure 3 were highly disordered, which caused a high R value. To resolve this issue, we removed the contribution of solvent electron density by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON. The hydrogen atoms of the ligands were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically with fixed thermal factors. Further details for structural analysis are summarized in Table , and selected bond lengths and angles for compounds 1-3 are listed in Table .

Symmetry modes for 1: #1 −x + 2, y, −z + 3/2; for 2: #2 −x + 2, −y +1, −z + 1; #3 x + 1, −y + 3/2, z + 1/2; #4 −x + 1, y − 1/2, −z + 1/2.

{[Co(L1)2](ClO4)2}∞ (1). Compound 1 crystallizes in a monoclinic space group C2/c with one homoleptic CoII node located on a crystallographic 2-fold axis of rotation. As shown in Figure a, each CoII ion lies in a tetrahedral coordination environment of four basal N-donors from independent L 1 ligands, with the Co−N bond lengths being 1.996(6) and 2.006(6) Å, respectively. The bidentate ligand L 1 , adopting a trans-coordinated conformation, bridges two adjacent CoII centers. In such a way, the tetrahedral coordinated CoII ions are linked by the ligand L 1 into a three-dimensional adamantoid array (Figure b), leaving bis-adamantane cavities inside the framework {[Co(L 1 ) 2 ] 2+ }∞ . Each bis-adamantane cage is composed of fourteen CoII nodes, which further form six chair-shaped hexagons, with Co···Co separation of 13.357 and 13.504 Å, respectively. Because of spacious edges, the bis-adamantane cage is large enough to accommodate four CoII nodes, which belong to two other symmetry-equivalent adamantane cages (Figure c). These above bis-adamantane cages extend into three identical 3D frameworks, and therefore the overall structure of 1 gives rise to a 3-fold interpenetrating diamondoid network (Figure d). Because of the neutral ligand L 1 , the framework {[Co(L 1 ) 2 ] 2+ }∞ is cationic, and thus the disordered ClO4 − anions are dispersed in the interpenetrating network to balance the positive charge.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure

 {[Co(L1)2](ClO4)2}∞  (1). Compound 1 crystallizes in a monoclinic space group C2/c with one homoleptic CoII node located on a crystallographic 2-fold axis of rotation. As shown in Figure a, each CoII ion lies in a tetrahedral coordination environment of four basal N-donors from independent L  1  ligands, with the Co-N bond lengths being 1.996(6) and 2.006(6) Å, respectively. The bidentate ligand L  1 , adopting a trans-coordinated conformation, bridges two adjacent CoII centers. In such a way, the tetrahedral coordinated CoII ions are linked by the ligand L  1  into a three-dimensional adamantoid array (Figure b), leaving bis-adamantane cavities inside the framework {[Co(L  1  )  2  ]  2+  }∞ . Each bis-adamantane cage is composed of fourteen CoII nodes, which further form six chair-shaped hexagons, with Co⋅⋅⋅Co separation of 13.357 and 13.504 Å, respectively. Because of spacious edges, the bis-adamantane cage is large enough to accommodate four CoII nodes, which belong to two other symmetry-equivalent adamantane cages (Figure c). These above bis-adamantane cages extend into three identical 3D frameworks, and therefore the overall structure of 1 gives rise to a 3-fold interpenetrating diamondoid network (Figure d). Because of the neutral ligand L  1 , the framework {[Co(L  1  )  2  ]  2+  }∞ is cationic, and thus the disordered ClO4 - anions are dispersed in the interpenetrating network to balance the positive charge.

elements.content: Although interpenetrating diamondoid networks are common in coordination polymers with the interpenetration degree from 2 to 12, compound 1 exhibits an interesting 3-fold interpenetrating diamond-related network based on homoleptic CoII nodes bound through benzoimidazole rings.
elements.clean_text: Although interpenetrating diamondoid networks are common in coordination polymers with the interpenetration degree from 2 to 12, compound 1 exhibits an interesting 3-fold interpenetrating diamond-related network based on homoleptic CoII nodes bound through benzoimidazole rings.

elements.content: View of (a) coordination environment in 1 (hydrogen omitted for clarity); (b) schematic plot of the diamondoid array in 1; (c) schematic depiction of ternary adamantanoid cages in 1; (d) 3-fold interpenetrating diamondoid network of 1.
elements.clean_text: 1  View of (a) coordination environment in 1 (hydrogen omitted for clarity); (b) schematic plot of the diamondoid array in 1; (c) schematic depiction of ternary adamantanoid cages in 1; (d) 3-fold interpenetrating diamondoid network of 1.

elements.content: {[Co(L2)3](ClO4)2(CHCl3)2}∞ (2). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. The geometry of the CoII ion is octahedrally surrounded by six imidazole rings of distinct L 2 ligands. The coordination bond lengths (d Co−N) that involve CoII ion and nitrogen atom of L 2 ligand are 2.189(2) and 2.153(2) Å, respectively. The axial angles are almost 180°, and other angles around CoII nodes are about 90° (Table ), which illustrates that the CoII ion has a slightly distorted octahedral coordination geometry. Notably, as shown in Figure a, the six-coordinated CoII center is bridged by linear ligand L 2 to form a “hexa-star” motif. The aggregation of the “hexa-star” motif results in an infinite helical architecture along crystallographic a axis. The helical pitch, given by the distance between equivalent atoms generated by one full rotation of the 3-fold screw axis, is 16.192 Å, and 13.705 Å for one-third of full rotation. As a consequence, it leads to the generation of a trigonal chiral aperture with the dimension of approximately 12.9 × 11.9 × 11.9 Å3 in cross-section. These trigonal apertures are packed in an antiparallel manner with different chirality, leading to a centrosymmetric and achiral coordination polymer (Figure b). Furthermore, the void space in the aperture is occupied by ClO4 − counterions and chloroform molecules, which destroy the porosity (Figure c).
elements.clean_text: {[Co(L2)3](ClO4)2(CHCl3)2}∞  (2). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. The geometry of the CoII ion is octahedrally surrounded by six imidazole rings of distinct L  2  ligands. The coordination bond lengths (d Co-N) that involve CoII ion and nitrogen atom of L  2  ligand are 2.189(2) and 2.153(2) Å, respectively. The axial angles are almost 180°, and other angles around CoII nodes are about 90° (Table ), which illustrates that the CoII ion has a slightly distorted octahedral coordination geometry. Notably, as shown in Figure a, the six-coordinated CoII center is bridged by linear ligand L  2  to form a "hexa-star" motif. The aggregation of the "hexa-star" motif results in an infinite helical architecture along crystallographic a axis. The helical pitch, given by the distance between equivalent atoms generated by one full rotation of the 3-fold screw axis, is 16.192 Å, and 13.705 Å for one-third of full rotation. As a consequence, it leads to the generation of a trigonal chiral aperture with the dimension of approximately 12.9 × 11.9 × 11.9 Å3 in cross-section. These trigonal apertures are packed in an antiparallel manner with different chirality, leading to a centrosymmetric and achiral coordination polymer (Figure b). Furthermore, the void space in the aperture is occupied by ClO4 - counterions and chloroform molecules, which destroy the porosity (Figure c).

elements.content: The most fascinating structural feature of 2 is that the trigonal aperture is reinforced with another 1D helix from the second framework. That is to say, each aperture is surrounded by two independent helices from equivalent frameworks. Further topological analysis suggests that each framework can be described as cross-linking layer of (4,4) lattices, bridged by colinear connections to form a pcu (α-po) array. Thus, these two independent identical frameworks are interlocked with each other to form a double interpenetrating α-po network (Figure d).
elements.clean_text: The most fascinating structural feature of 2 is that the trigonal aperture is reinforced with another 1D helix from the second framework. That is to say, each aperture is surrounded by two independent helices from equivalent frameworks. Further topological analysis suggests that each framework can be described as cross-linking layer of (4,4) lattices, bridged by colinear connections to form a pcu (α-po) array. Thus, these two independent identical frameworks are interlocked with each other to form a double interpenetrating α-po network (Figure d).

elements.content: View of (a) octahedral coordination environment and hexa-star extended CoII node in 2; (b) the schematic representation of heterochiral channel in 2; (c) ClO4 − anions and chloroform molecules included in the channel; (d) interpenetrating network with α-po 41263 topology of 2.
elements.clean_text: 2  View of (a) octahedral coordination environment and hexa-star extended CoII node in 2; (b) the schematic representation of heterochiral channel in 2; (c) ClO4 - anions and chloroform molecules included in the channel; (d) interpenetrating network with α-po 41263 topology of 2.

elements.content: {[Co(L3)3](ClO4)2}∞ (3). Similar to 2, compound 3 also crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c and maintains a homoleptic CoII coordination environment. The CoII ion is octahedrally coordinated by six nitrogen atoms from individual L 3 ligands. The bond lengths associated with the CoII ion and imidazole nitrogen atoms span a narrow range [2.147(6)−2.197(5) Å]. However, quite different from compound 2, the “hexa-star” motif of 3 is distorted, and two axial spokes are a little twisted (Figure a). As a result, the structures change from an α-po net in 2 to an unusual β-Sn net in 3. As shown in Figure b, the darker CoII ions lie on the crystal plane (101̅), while the transparent CoII ions lie one and a half unit cells below this plane. There are also trigonal channels in β-Sn network, but the metal nodes are interlaced along the expanded direction of channels. To the best of our knowledge, compound 3 shows the first example of β-Sn topology exclusively based upon coordination bonds. Significantly, view along crystallographic b axis, compound 3 represents a single-stranded helix, different from the infinite double helices in 2. Within this helix, the Co···Co separation ranges from 16.988 to 18.124 Å, and a 1D square-shaped chiral channel is formed. However, these channels are packed in an antiparallel manner with different chirality (Figure c). In such a case, this compound is centrosymmetric and achiral solid. Simultaneously, the large void space provided by the square-shapped channel is filled with two equivalent β-Sn frameworks. Thus, as we are aware, 3 represents a unique 3-fold interpenetrating β-Sn network (Figure d). Besides, the remaining space among the three interpenetrating {[Co(L 3 ) 3 ] 2+ }∞ frameworks is occupied by perchlorate anions and chloroform solvent molecules.
elements.clean_text: {[Co(L3)3](ClO4)2}∞  (3). Similar to 2, compound 3 also crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c and maintains a homoleptic CoII coordination environment. The CoII ion is octahedrally coordinated by six nitrogen atoms from individual L  3  ligands. The bond lengths associated with the CoII ion and imidazole nitrogen atoms span a narrow range [2.147(6)-2.197(5) Å]. However, quite different from compound 2, the "hexa-star" motif of 3 is distorted, and two axial spokes are a little twisted (Figure a). As a result, the structures change from an α-po net in 2 to an unusual β-Sn net in 3. As shown in Figure b, the darker CoII ions lie on the crystal plane (101̅), while the transparent CoII ions lie one and a half unit cells below this plane. There are also trigonal channels in β-Sn network, but the metal nodes are interlaced along the expanded direction of channels. To the best of our knowledge, compound 3 shows the first example of β-Sn topology exclusively based upon coordination bonds. Significantly, view along crystallographic b axis, compound 3 represents a single-stranded helix, different from the infinite double helices in 2. Within this helix, the Co⋅⋅⋅Co separation ranges from 16.988 to 18.124 Å, and a 1D square-shaped chiral channel is formed. However, these channels are packed in an antiparallel manner with different chirality (Figure c). In such a case, this compound is centrosymmetric and achiral solid. Simultaneously, the large void space provided by the square-shapped channel is filled with two equivalent β-Sn frameworks. Thus, as we are aware, 3 represents a unique 3-fold interpenetrating β-Sn network (Figure d). Besides, the remaining space among the three interpenetrating {[Co(L  3  )  3  ]  2+  }∞  frameworks is occupied by perchlorate anions and chloroform solvent molecules.

elements.content: View of (a) coordination environment in 3 (hydrogen atoms omitted for clarity); (b) schematic diagram of β-Sn topology in 3; inset, the ideal β-Sn net; (c) schematic depiction of different chiral channels in 3; (d) 3-fold interpenetrating network with β-Sn topology of 3.
elements.clean_text: 3  View of (a) coordination environment in 3 (hydrogen atoms omitted for clarity); (b) schematic diagram of β-Sn topology in 3; inset, the ideal β-Sn net; (c) schematic depiction of different chiral channels in 3; (d) 3-fold interpenetrating network with β-Sn topology of 3.

elements.content: Compounds 1−3 are coordination polymers with different interpenetrating networks based on CoII nodes linked by structurally related rodlike ligands L 1 −L 3 . These results indicate that the ligand backbones (including ligands spacers and terminal groups) have great effect on the complex formation and may adjust the degree of interpenetration of coordination polymers. The size of terminal groups may affect the coordination environment of the metal ions. In complex 1 (the ligand has a larger benzoimidazolyl terminal group), the CoII ion is tetra-coordinated while in complexes 2 and 3 (the terminal group is a much smaller imidazolyl group), CoII nodes are six-connected. Such differences in coordination geometry greatly affect the final networks of the three complexes. The assembly of ligand L 1 with tetrahedrally coordinated CoII center affords a bis-adamantane close box in compound 1, and further forms a 3-fold interpenetrating network. However, compound 2 with octahedrally coordinated CoII node, forms a 2-fold interpenetrating primitive cubic array. Although L 1 and L 2 have the same ligand spacer, compound 1 takes more tightly packed interpenetration, which is attributable to the large bis-adamantane cavity.
elements.clean_text:
Effects of Ligand Backbones

Compounds 1-3 are coordination polymers with different interpenetrating networks based on CoII nodes linked by structurally related rodlike ligands L  1 -L  3 . These results indicate that the ligand backbones (including ligands spacers and terminal groups) have great effect on the complex formation and may adjust the degree of interpenetration of coordination polymers. The size of terminal groups may affect the coordination environment of the metal ions. In complex 1 (the ligand has a larger benzoimidazolyl terminal group), the CoII ion is tetra-coordinated while in complexes 2 and 3 (the terminal group is a much smaller imidazolyl group), CoII nodes are six-connected. Such differences in coordination geometry greatly affect the final networks of the three complexes. The assembly of ligand L  1  with tetrahedrally coordinated CoII center affords a bis-adamantane close box in compound 1, and further forms a 3-fold interpenetrating network. However, compound 2 with octahedrally coordinated CoII node, forms a 2-fold interpenetrating primitive cubic array. Although L  1  and L  2  have the same ligand spacer, compound 1 takes more tightly packed interpenetration, which is attributable to the large bis-adamantane cavity.

elements.content: Evidently, there is more vacant space to allow mutual interpenetration as the length of spacer increases. The degree of interpenetration is then greatly related to the ligand spacer. Compounds 2 and 3 are both six-connected complexes, constructed from ligands L 2 and L 3 , respectively. Ligand L 3 can be viewed as a derivative of L 2 by ligand elongation from phenyl to biphenyl. As a result, compound 3 illustrates a 3-fold interpenetrating network, and yet a 2-fold interpenetrating network formed in 2. Therefore, when increasing the length of ligand spacer, a higher degree of interpenetration may be preferential, and the degree of interpenetration increases with the increasing of the spacer length. This hypothesis of interpenetrating degree was also supported in many reported cases. Furthermore, the L 3 molecule is more liable to get twisted in the self-assembly progress of the coordination polymer because of its longer spacer. Probably because of the minor distortion of L 3 molecules, an unusual topology β-Sn 485463 was induced in compound 3. In this case, parallel or coplanar layers of (4,4) nets are only observed along crystallographic a and c axes, and yet a single-stranded helix is depicted along crystallographic b axis. It implies that there exists no primitive cubic box. However, the structure of 2 can be described as comprising three intersecting (4,4) nets that share connections to form a α-po 41263 topology network. From the topological symbol, it can be seen that 485463 net is quite different from the 41263 net, or other previously reported 6-connected nets. Significantly, as far as we know, compound 3 may be the first example of β-Sn topology in Co(II) coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text: Evidently, there is more vacant space to allow mutual interpenetration as the length of spacer increases. The degree of interpenetration is then greatly related to the ligand spacer. Compounds 2 and 3 are both six-connected complexes, constructed from ligands L  2  and L  3 , respectively. Ligand L  3  can be viewed as a derivative of L  2  by ligand elongation from phenyl to biphenyl. As a result, compound 3 illustrates a 3-fold interpenetrating network, and yet a 2-fold interpenetrating network formed in 2. Therefore, when increasing the length of ligand spacer, a higher degree of interpenetration may be preferential, and the degree of interpenetration increases with the increasing of the spacer length. This hypothesis of interpenetrating degree was also supported in many reported cases. Furthermore, the L  3  molecule is more liable to get twisted in the self-assembly progress of the coordination polymer because of its longer spacer. Probably because of the minor distortion of L  3  molecules, an unusual topology β-Sn 485463 was induced in compound 3. In this case, parallel or coplanar layers of (4,4) nets are only observed along crystallographic a and c axes, and yet a single-stranded helix is depicted along crystallographic b axis. It implies that there exists no primitive cubic box. However, the structure of 2 can be described as comprising three intersecting (4,4) nets that share connections to form a α-po 41263 topology network. From the topological symbol, it can be seen that 485463 net is quite different from the 41263 net, or other previously reported 6-connected nets. Significantly, as far as we know, compound 3 may be the first example of β-Sn topology in Co(II) coordination polymers.

elements.content: In summary, three new coordination polymers 1−3 based on homoleptic CoII nodes with three structurally related rodlike ligands bearing different backbones, have been synthesized and characterized, and provide new examples of entangled systems. Structural analysis indicates that ligand backbone (terminal group and ligand spacer) greatly affects the structural topology, because of terminal steric hindrance and conformation of spacer, respectively. Furthermore, detailed comparison of the interpenetrating degree of these networks reveals that the coordination mode and spacer length both play significant roles in determining the degree of interpenetration of coordination polymers. Therefore, the interpenetrating networks could be modified by varying terminal groups or ligand spacers, and hence modulation of the interpenetrating network could be achieved by varying ligand backbones.
elements.clean_text: In summary, three new coordination polymers 1-3 based on homoleptic CoII nodes with three structurally related rodlike ligands bearing different backbones, have been synthesized and characterized, and provide new examples of entangled systems. Structural analysis indicates that ligand backbone (terminal group and ligand spacer) greatly affects the structural topology, because of terminal steric hindrance and conformation of spacer, respectively. Furthermore, detailed comparison of the interpenetrating degree of these networks reveals that the coordination mode and spacer length both play significant roles in determining the degree of interpenetration of coordination polymers. Therefore, the interpenetrating networks could be modified by varying terminal groups or ligand spacers, and hence modulation of the interpenetrating network could be achieved by varying ligand backbones.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of 1,4-dibromophenyl (12.0 mmol), benzoimidazole (60.0 mmol), CuI (2.5 mmol), 1,10-phenanthroline (6.0 mmol), and K2CO3 (96.0 mmol) was suspended in 50 mL of DMF. The mixture was refluxed for ca. 5 days and then cooled to room temperature. The resulting residue was extracted with CH2Cl2 (50 mL × 3), and the organic extracts were combined, dried over MgSO4, and purified by column chromatography (v/v 2:1 CHCl3/CH3CO2Et) to afford L 1 as white powder (yield ∼35%, based on 1,4-dibromophenyl). 300-MHz 1H NMR (δ, CDCl3): 8.20 (2H, s), 7.93 (2H, m), 7.77 (4H, s), 7.62 (2H, m), 7.40 (4H, m). Anal. Calcd for C20H14N4: C, 77.40; H, 4.55; N, 18.05%. Found: C, 77.61; H, 4.45; N, 18.19. IR (KBr, cm −1): 3476s, 3416s, 3114m, 3064m, 3021m, 1612m, 1520s, 1486s, 1455s, 1277m, 1227s, 1146m, 978m, 892m, 845s, 746s, 633m, 589m, 503w, 438m. MS: m/z = 311.9 for (HL 1 )+.

Synthesis of <bold>{[Co(L<sup>1</sup>)<sub>2</sub>](ClO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>}<bold> <sub>∞</sub> </bold> </bold> (<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of C2H5OH and CHCl3 (1:1, 8 mL), as a buffer layer, was carefully layered over a solution of L 1 (0.06 mmol) in CHCl3 (6 mL). A solution of Co(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.02 mmol) in C2H5OH (6 mL) was then layered over the buffer layer, and the resultant reaction was left to stand at room temperature. After ca. 3 weeks, purple block single crystals appeared at the boundary. Yield: ∼30% (based on L 1 ). Anal. Calcd for C40H28CoCl2O8N8: C, 54.68; H, 3.21; N, 12.75%. Found: C, 54.88; H, 3.13; N, 12.63. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3472s, 3416s, 1641m, 1618m, 1524m, 1462s, 1295w, 1245m, 1123s, 1094s, 849m, 746w, 619s, 488w.

Single crystals of 2 and 3 suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained by the similar method as described for 1.

<bold>{[Co(L<sup>2</sup>)<sub>3</sub>](ClO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(CHCl<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>}<sub>∞</sub> </bold> (<bold>2</bold>)

Yield: ∼30% (based on L 2 ). IR (KBr, cm−1): 3596m, 3528m, 3131m, 3038w, 2012w, 1638w, 1530s, 1489m, 1442w, 1322m, 1306s, 1268w, 1245m, 1090s, 1074s, 962m, 933m, 834m, 763m, 659m, 622m, 548m, 491w, 449w.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 1,4-Bis(benzoimidazol-1-yl)phenyl (L1) 

A mixture of 1,4-dibromophenyl (12.0 mmol), benzoimidazole (60.0 mmol), CuI (2.5 mmol), 1,10-phenanthroline (6.0 mmol), and K2CO3 (96.0 mmol) was suspended in 50 mL of DMF. The mixture was refluxed for ca. 5 days and then cooled to room temperature. The resulting residue was extracted with CH2Cl2 (50 mL × 3), and the organic extracts were combined, dried over MgSO4, and purified by column chromatography (v/v 2:1 CHCl3/CH3CO2Et) to afford L  1  as white powder (yield ~35%, based on 1,4-dibromophenyl). 300-MHz 1H NMR (δ, CDCl3): 8.20 (2H, s), 7.93 (2H, m), 7.77 (4H, s), 7.62 (2H, m), 7.40 (4H, m). Anal. Calcd for C20H14N4: C, 77.40; H, 4.55; N, 18.05%. Found: C, 77.61; H, 4.45; N, 18.19. IR (KBr, cm -1): 3476s, 3416s, 3114m, 3064m, 3021m, 1612m, 1520s, 1486s, 1455s, 1277m, 1227s, 1146m, 978m, 892m, 845s, 746s, 633m, 589m, 503w, 438m. MS: m/z = 311.9 for (HL  1 )+.

Synthesis of {[Co(L1)2](ClO4)2} ∞   (1)

A mixture of C2H5OH and CHCl3 (1:1, 8 mL), as a buffer layer, was carefully layered over a solution of L  1  (0.06 mmol) in CHCl3 (6 mL). A solution of Co(ClO4)2⋅6H2O (0.02 mmol) in C2H5OH (6 mL) was then layered over the buffer layer, and the resultant reaction was left to stand at room temperature. After ca. 3 weeks, purple block single crystals appeared at the boundary. Yield: ~30% (based on L  1 ). Anal. Calcd for C40H28CoCl2O8N8: C, 54.68; H, 3.21; N, 12.75%. Found: C, 54.88; H, 3.13; N, 12.63. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3472s, 3416s, 1641m, 1618m, 1524m, 1462s, 1295w, 1245m, 1123s, 1094s, 849m, 746w, 619s, 488w.

Single crystals of 2 and 3 suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained by the similar method as described for 1.

 {[Co(L2)3](ClO4)2(CHCl3)2}∞  (2)

Yield: ~30% (based on L  2 ). IR (KBr, cm-1): 3596m, 3528m, 3131m, 3038w, 2012w, 1638w, 1530s, 1489m, 1442w, 1322m, 1306s, 1268w, 1245m, 1090s, 1074s, 962m, 933m, 834m, 763m, 659m, 622m, 548m, 491w, 449w.

metadata.title: Varying Ligand Backbones for Modulating the Interpenetration of Coordination Polymers Based on Homoleptic Cobalt(II) Nodes
